cotton_plant_diseases.description: A bacterial disease that causes dark, angular spots on leaves and water-soaked lesions.
causes: Infection by Xanthomonas citri pv. malvacearum

cotton_plant_diseases.description: A viral disease spread by whiteflies, causing curling and distortion of leaves.
causes: Infection by Cotton leaf curl virus (CLCuV)

cotton_plant_diseases.description: A fungal disease that causes wilting and yellowing of cotton plants.
causes: Infection by Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. vasinfectum
treatment: Rotate crops to reduce pathogen build-up

cotton_plant_diseases.description: No signs of disease; leaves are green and healthy.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease

orange_plant_diseases.description: A bacterial disease caused by Candidatus Liberibacter species, spread by psyllids, leading to mottled leaves, stunted growth, and bitter, misshapen fruit.
symptoms: Bitter, misshapen fruit with uneven ripening
causes: Transmission by Asian citrus psyllid (Diaphorina citri)
treatment: Remove and destroy infected trees to prevent spread
Apply insecticides to control psyllid populations
Maintain good nutrition and irrigation for healthy trees
prevention: Using reflective mulches to repel psyllids
Quarantine and movement restrictions in affected areas

rice_plant_diseases.description: A bacterial disease caused by Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae, leading to leaf wilting and yield loss.
symptoms: Yellow to white water-soaked streaks on leaves
Wilting and drying of leaves in severe cases
causes: Infection by Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae
prevention: Rotate crops to break the disease cycle

soybean_plant_diseases.description: A bacterial disease caused by Pseudomonas syringae pv. glycinea, resulting in water-soaked lesions on leaves.
symptoms: Spots enlarge and turn brown with yellow margins
Leaves may tear and drop prematurely
causes: Infection by Pseudomonas syringae pv. glycinea
Rain splash and wind spreading the bacteria
treatment: Avoid working in fields when plants are wet
prevention: Practice crop rotation to reduce pathogen build-up
Ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging

soybean_plant_diseases.description: A fungal disease caused by Septoria glycines, leading to small, irregular brown spots on leaves.
symptoms: Small, irregular brown spots on lower leaves
Leaves may turn yellow and drop prematurely
causes: Prolonged leaf wetness and high humidity
Overcrowded planting and poor air circulation
treatment: Apply fungicides like Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb
Improve airflow by proper plant spacing
prevention: Rotate crops to break the disease cycle

soybean_plant_diseases.description: A fungal disease caused by Microsphaera diffusa, forming white, powdery patches on leaf surfaces.
symptoms: White, powdery fungal growth on upper leaf surfaces
Leaves may curl, yellow, and drop
treatment: Apply fungicides such as Sulfur or Triazole-based products
prevention: Regularly monitor plants for early signs of infection

soybean_plant_diseases.description: A viral disease caused by Yellow Mosaic Virus, leading to yellow patches and distorted leaves.
symptoms: Yellow and green mosaic patterns on leaves
Stunted plant growth and reduced yield
treatment: Spray neem-based bio-pesticides for whitefly control
prevention: Use reflective mulches to repel whiteflies
Practice good field hygiene and weed control

wheat_plant_diseases.description: A fungal disease caused by Zymoseptoria tritici, leading to leaf lesions and reduced photosynthesis.
symptoms: Spots enlarge into elongated lesions with gray-brown centers
Black fruiting bodies (pycnidia) visible in lesions
causes: Spread by wind and rain splash
treatment: Apply fungicides such as Azoxystrobin or Propiconazole
prevention: Rotate crops to break the disease cycle
Ensure proper spacing for good air circulation

wheat_plant_diseases.description: A fungal disease caused by Puccinia striiformis f. sp. tritici, forming yellow-orange pustules on leaves.
symptoms: Yellow to orange pustules forming linear stripes on leaves
Reduced plant vigor and grain filling
causes: Infection by Puccinia striiformis f. sp. tritici
Spores spread by wind over long distances
treatment: Apply fungicides such as Tebuconazole or Triazole-based products
Remove volunteer wheat plants to reduce spore sources
prevention: Monitor crops regularly for early signs of infection
Rotate crops to minimize pathogen build-up

wheat_plant_diseases.description: Wheat leaves with no visible signs of disease, characterized by green, unblemished foliage.
treatment: Continue monitoring for early signs of disease
